name: Channel Evolution Stage & Trends
functionStatement: Long-term changes in channel size and slope maintain dynamic equilibrium and diverse habitats while interacting with the floodplain.
descriptionMarkdown:
Channel is stable/recovered (Stage I/VI or 0,1,6,8), not actively degrading, unless partial evolution is normal.
No active headcuts or fully stabilized ones; no ongoing incision or bank widening.
Channel shows vegetated benches/floodplain formation, indicating recovery from incision/widening.
Bank erosion/migration rates match natural reference; no excessive widening unless historically typical.
howToMeasureMarkdown:
Assess channel evolution stage using field indicators or recent geomorphic reports. Use desktop review only for coarse screening.
Locate headcuts or knickpoints and estimate migration using multi-date elevation or imagery. Confirm in the field.
Identify vegetated benches or inset floodplains and track their extent using imagery and elevation profiles where available.
Map active channel edges across years and compute width change using imagery and field indicators where feasible.

inputs.label: Channel Evolution Stage & Trends
inputs.helpMarkdown: High resolution aerial imagery; Field photos; Brief field recon; Historical evidence

levels.label: Good
levels.criteriaMarkdown: Good: Stable or re-stabilized channel (Stage I or VI). (Suggested index range 0.70-1.0)

levels.label: Fair
levels.criteriaMarkdown: Fair: Partially recovered channel (often Stage V). / Actively widening or incising (often Stage III-IV). (Suggested index range 0.40-0.69)

levels.label: Poor
levels.criteriaMarkdown: Poor: Severe incision or destructive phases (often Stage II or severe III-IV). (Suggested index range 0.0-0.29)

references: repeat LiDAR for DEM of Difference (where available)
NAIP or Google Earth time series.
USGS 3DEP LiDAR cross sections and elevation profiles
NAIP or orthophotos for benches and bars.
NAIP or Google Earth historical imagery
